questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vossius ring Vossius ring is a well-circumscribed complete or incomplete ring of pigment deposition on the anterior lens capsule surface , usually as a result of significant blunt eye trauma. It is asymptomatic and generally will improve or resolve with time. It is a result of compression of the pigmented posterior iris epithelial cells and/or pupillary ruff against the anterior lens capsule with abrupt blunt force to the eye. Rupture of the cells causes deposition of a circular line of melanin pigment on the lens capsule. The ring of pigment is generally the same diameter as the undilated pupil. Uveitis is another well-known cause of pigment deposition on the lens surface. Intraocular inflammation can result in formation of posterior synechiae. With resolution of inflammation or pharmacologic mydriasis , the synechiae can leave patchy clumps and fragments of pigment on the anterior lens capsule. Uveitis can be distinguished from the Vossius ring based on history and presence of other ocular signs of inflammation including:- cell and flare in the anterior chamber, hypopyon, keratic precipitates, presence of systemic inflammatory disease, etc. KF rings are caused by deposition of excess copper on the inner surface of the peripheral cornea in the Descemet membrane , resulting from iron deposition in basal epithelial cells , in the form of hemosiderin . They are usually yellowish to dark-brown, and may be complete or broken . The rings are best seen using a slit lamp under a cobalt blue filter. A Weiss ring is a much larger, ring-shaped floater that is created by a posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) from around the optic nerve head.

Extraedge:

Blunt Trauma Of The Eye:- LENS VOSSIUS RING : It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule It occurs due to striking of contracted pupillary margin against the lens. CONCUSSION CATARACT: due to imbibition of aqueous and due to direct mechanical effects of the injury on lens fibers

questions.text: Which cerebral lobe controls coordination of eye and hand movements?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Parietal lobe The parietal lobe is behind the frontal lobe , separated by the central sulcus. Areas in the parietal lobe are responsible for:- integrating sensory information, including touch, temperature, pressure, two-point discrimination, pain and hand-eye coordination. The primary somatosensory cortex , located in the post rolandic area (postcentral gyrus) in the anterior parietal lobes , integrates somesthetic stimuli for recognition and recall of form, texture, and weight. Areas posterolateral to the postcentral gyrus generate visual-spatial relationships and integrate these perceptions with other sensations to create awareness of trajectories of moving objects. Parts of the MID parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere are involved in abilities such as:- calculation, writing, left-right orientation, and finger recognition. The nondominant parietal lobe integrates the contralateral side of the body with its environment, enabling people to be aware of this environmental space, and is important for abilities such as drawing. Acute injury to the nondominant parietal lobe may cause neglect of the contralateral side (usually the left), resulting in decreased awareness of that part of the body , its environment , and any associated injury to that side ( anosognosia ).

Highyeild:

Lesions in the angular gyrus can cause:- deficits in writing, calculating, left-right disorientation, and finger-naming (Gerstmann syndrome)

Extraedge:

The frontal lobe is generally where higher executive functions including:- emotional regulation, planning, reasoning and problem solving occur. This is why in frontotemporal dementia , personality changes are often the first signs of the disease. The temporal lobe contains regions dedicated to processing sensory information, particularly important for hearing, recognizing language, and forming memories. The occipital lobe is the major visual processing centre in the brain. The primary visual cortex , also known as V1 , receives visual information from the eyes, which is related to several secondary visual processing areas, which interpret depth, distance, location and the identity of seen objects.

Solution:

Hess chart Hess Chart is shown in the given image. Diplopia Charting vs Hess Chart: Diplopia Charting is the record of separation of the diplopic or double images in the nine positions of gaze and is especially important in patients who are bedridden , have torsional diplopia or Hess chart plotting is not possible. It can be plotted in patients who cooperate and can appreciate the double vision and with incomitant or comitant deviation. The light is carried to both eyes and tested with all positions of gaze. In the direction of the action of the paralyzed muscle , the double vision or the separation would be greatest because of the under action of the muscle and overaction of the antagonist muscle and yoke muscle. HESS Charting:- It aids in the diagnosis of ocular motility defects by measuring the deviation and the amount of underaction and overaction of muscles . It is a repeatable and reliable record of the condition and is, therefore, a good way to show improvement or deterioration of the condition . The principle is the foveal projection. The chart is plotted based on Hering’s and Sherrington’s law of innervation . The dissociation of two eyes is by the means of colors or mirrors (as in Less screen). Now foster torches are used for projection of the target. There is an illuminated Hess screen on which each target can be lit up in turn and its position indicated by the patient using a linear green light. Less screens used the principle of the mirror. NEAR VISION ETDRS CHART: Pelli Robson contrast sensitivity chart:

Uses of Hess Chart:- which muscle is affected degree of paresis extent of development of muscle sequelae differentiate recent onset/ longstanding differentiate mechanical/neurogenic measurement of deviation (each little square is Assess change over time which muscle to operate on effect of treatment

Extraedge:

INO INO is a lesion of the Medial longitudinal fascicules (MLF) resulting in a palsy of the MR muscle and a dissociated gaze evoked nystagmus in the abducting eye. Clinical & diagnostic features: The principal feature is abducting nystagmus. Limitation of the MR of the affected eye in adduction during conjugate There is usually an exophoria or exotropia in the primary position. Which increases in the direction of affected MR in horizontal gaze movement.

questions.text: A 14 days old neonate developed conjunctivitis followed by pneumonitis showing bilateral infiltrated and TLC showing lymphocytic predominance. What may be the etiological agent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chlamydia trachomatis Given scenario is a classic case of Chlamydial infection. Infected women frequently transmit C. trachomatis infection to their infants during birth. Vaginal delivery is the usual route of transmission of C. trachomatis from infected mother to infant, as the eyes are coated with chlamydia as the baby passes down the birth canal. Maternally-acquired infection with C. trachomatis is the commonest cause of neonatal conjunctivitis in industrially developed countries and it is a significant cause of this condition in the developing world . Conjunctivitis develops between 5-14 days after delivery, usually in one eye but affecting the other after 2-7 days. Oedema and erythema of the eyelids is common , along with an eye discharge that may be watery initially, but becoming purulent later. Although chlamydia conjunctivitis is usually mild , infection of the hair follicles will increase the amount of discharge and prolong the period of infection. The most serious complication of neonatal chlamydia infection is pneumonia caused by nasopharyngeal C. trachomatis infection or aspiration of infected genital secretions during delivery. A chest X-ray will show hyperinflation and diffuse infiltrates.

Highyeild:

Signs - Upper tarsal conjunctiva - mc affected, appears red velvety, congested Trachomatous follicle - essential lesion , upto 5mm size characteristic distribution - upper fornix(mc), upper margin of tarsus, palpebral conjunctiva Scarring of conjunctiva Arlt's line Limbal follicles Herbert pits - oval/pitted scars in limbus

Extraedge:

WHO CLASSIFICATION(FISTO) TRACHOMATOUS FOLLICULAR(TF) Active disease 5 or more follicles of › 0.5mm on upper tarsus Deep conjunctival vessels seen If treated properly- no scarring TRACHOMA INTENSE Severe disease, needs urgents rx diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present TRACHOMATOUS SCARRING- Inactive infection conjunctival scarring visible fibrous white bands on tarsal conjunctiva TRACHOMATOUS TRICHIASIS Needs corrective surgery CORNEAL OPACITY sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants should be avoided in acute angle closure glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amitriptyline Amitriptyline has a marked anticholinergic activity due to high affinity for blockade of muscarinic Ach receptors, especially M3-R. The receptors can cause mild pupillary dilation and contraction of iris sphincter , ciliary muscles and trabecular meshwork along with increased aqueous humor outflow. The inhibition of these receptors can thus lead to an episode of angle-closure glaucoma mediated by an antimuscarinic effect . Apart from this, acute angle closure glaucoma due to pupillary block , treatable by peripheral iridotomy , can be caused by adrenergic agents, either locally (phenylephrine drops, nasal ephedrine, or nebulized salbutamol) or systemically (epinephrine for anaphylactic shock), drugs with anticholinergic effects including tropicamide and atropine drops, tri and tetracyclic antidepressants , and cholinergic agents like pilocarpine . Sulfa-based drugs (acetazolamide, hydrochlorothiazide, cotrimoxazole, and topiramate) can cause acute angle closure glaucoma by ciliary body edema with anterior rotation of the iris-lens diaphragm.

Highyeild:

ACUTE CONGESTIVE ANGLE CLOSURE GLAUCOMA Due to rapid ⬆️ in 10P Defined as: At least 2 of the following SYMPTOMS Ocular pain Nausea/ vomiting Hx of intermittent BOV with halos Plus 3 of the following SIGNS IOP > 21mmHg Conjunctival injection Corneal epithelial edema Mid-dilated non reactive pupil Shallower chamber in presence of occlusion

Extraedge:

Closed-angle glaucomas are characterized by a shallow anterior chamber that forces the root of the mid-dilated iris forward against the trabecular network, obstructing the drainage of aqueous humor and increasing the intraocular pressure. SIGNS Reduced visual acuity Cornea cloudy and oedematous Pupil oval, fixed and moderately dilated Ciliary injection Eye feels hard on palpation Elevated IOP (50-100 mmHg) Narrow chamber Angle with peripheral Aqueous flare and cells Gonioscopy - complete peripheral iridocorneal contact Ophthalmoscopy - optic disc oedema and hyperaemia

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common ocular manifestation of Covid 19?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Follicular conjunctivitis Several ocular manifestations of COVID-19 have been observed due to the presence of ACE-2 receptor in cornea , conjunctiva as we as human type 2 epithelial cells, including:- neurovascular disease, uveitis, optic neuropathies, and orbital fungal co-infections . Conjunctivitis or tearing can be the first presentation and even sole manifestation in a patient with the COVID-19 infection. The most common presentation however, is mild follicular conjunctivitis. Ocular shedding of SARS-CoV-2 via tears is a distinct possibility . SARS-CoV-2 can be detected in RT-PCR by sweeping the lower eyelid Fornices to collect tears and conjunctival secretions with a virus sampling swab.

Highyeild:

Clinical Features:- photophobia, acute follicular or membranous conjunctivitis, subepithelial infiltrates in the cornea, scanty discharge and preauricular lymphadenopathy. Pseudomembrane on the palpebral conjunctiva develops predominantly. Petechial hemorrhages on bulbar conjunctiva and subconjunctival hemorrhages can occur. Diffuse punctate epithelial keratitis is the earliest corneal lesion. Stromal corneal infiltrates develop within two weeks time due to immune response to the adenovirus .

Extraedge:

Follicular conjunctivitis: It is conjunctivitis associated with hypertrophic lymphoid tissue as pinkish round bodies in the conjunctival fornices; can be acute or chronic. Histology of Follicular conjunctivitis: regular follicles plasma cells pannus pmnc infiltration by lymphocyte no true capsule
